instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Hello guys,

I worked the past few hours on a 3332 Logicboard and I can't get it back to life.
The one-wire circuit is working but there is no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> power rail. I tried to figure out why but I am stuck.
Every time I look through the schematics, I end up at the Panther-Point-Mobile (guess thats the PCH) and when I look on I end up at the power rails. It is like an infinite loop.
I hope someone can help me.

Thanks a lot!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: History of the machine? Got green then orange light? PPBUS voltage? Are you using a REAL GENUINE APPLE 85W charger?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Hello,

the machine suddenly turned black while working, no signs of liquid damage.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.61V, it has a green light for 3 seconds and then it switches over to an orange light on the charger.
Yes, it is a REAL GENUINE APPLE 85W charger.

Thank you!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Do you have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ?

Voltage on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: Yes, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present and I got 3.361 Volts on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> (3.434V on pin 1)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> present?

I still suspect that adapter, these do not power on from anything that is not 85W.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Hello,
yes <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is present (2.4V).
Yesterday I bought a new charger from the Apple Store and it started working again, but suddenly the machine died again.

After the machine died, I heard a ticking noise when I attached the charger. I then replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> which stopped the ticking noise but the machine wont turn on.

[B]My power rails:[/B]
- <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = [B][COLOR=#DAA520][U]16.69V[/U][/COLOR][/B]
- G3H & 3V42 present

- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V!!![/B][/COLOR]
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 1.4V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V!!![/B][/COLOR]
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V!!![/B][/COLOR]

- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V[/B][/COLOR]
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 1.56V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V[/B][/COLOR]
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V[/B][/COLOR]

[B]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> measurements:[/B]
- VIN = 12.61V
- EN2 = 3.41V
- EN1 = [COLOR=#FF0000][B]0V[/B][/COLOR]

now when I look up where EN1 comes from, I get to [B]<CHIP>U7970</CHIP>[/B] which should theoretically be enabled when <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL>
is present. But the problem is that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> comes from [B]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/B] which depends on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL>. This is a infinite loop. What can I do?

[B]<CHIP>U7970</CHIP> measurements:[/B]
- Pin 6 (Enable) = 1.5V

Thank you a lot!!!
[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>IMG_6410</SIGNAL>.JPG" type="full" width="200px"]21445._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is a simple LDO from <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Check enable at pin 12 and check for short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. PPBUS still present and 12.6v?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Hello,

I get 3.41V at pin 12 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 1.4V at <CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> (very very slowly increasing voltage - from 0V to 1.4 approx. 30 sec.)

Yes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.6V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: Well <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> should be present then if there is no short on that bus. So either dead <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> or bad traces/soldering. VIN pin 23 is also a common suspect.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
I just replaced [B]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/B] for testing purposes and I think now I have a fully working chip but the ticking noise is back.
I now have clean [B]5V on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>[/B] but when I hear a tick on the logicboard, the voltage on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> [B]drops[/B] [B]to 3V[/B] for a few milliseconds.
I think thats probably the issue why nothing is working but where does this ticking come from? SMC?

And I have 12V on pin 23 (VIN) of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: Ticking is probably from a coil. I bet you didnt eliminate the inital ticking noise.....then again unreliable rail can also cause coil making ticking noose.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
I also guessed the noise came from a coil but I can't figure out which

what do you mean with "unreliable rail can also cause coil making ticking noose"?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: you can start by check all the coils used in S4/S5 state. like L6995. you dont need to check coils use for screen, keyboard backlight and thunderbolt.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: Ok, thank you. Do you mean I should check them for a short inside the coil or infinite resistance or... ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: Check for short to GND on L7220 or L7260.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
I checked all coils and I couldn't find a single short. 
The wired thing I found is that when I removed <CAPACITOR>C9823</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9848</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9849</CAPACITOR> the ticking stopped except one tick at the beginning. I now replaced these three parts but nothing changed. noise still there.
I am kind of clueless..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Is the machine power cycling? It sounds like it is running into a short somewhere. Check all rails for shorts including all S3 and S0 rails. 
Was this liquid damage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: by this time, i would start injecting voltages into each rail to see when the noise is coming from and check if anything gets hot..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Hello,

Thank you guys, I now fixed my ticking issue! it was some come kind of corrosion or some nasty stuff near <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> which caused a short. (The board was officially not liquid damaged)

Now the fan spins but while checking all the coils I realized that I have a short on L7510, L7520, L7530, L7550, L7560, L8930, L8960 (the coils under the black tape).
Basically the CPU get very hot very fast and when I go over the circuits for Phase 1,2,3 and AXG Phase 1,2 I see a short to ground on the [B]<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE</SIGNAL>[COLOR=#FF0000]XX[/COLOR][/B] rails. Is there a way to check the all transistors (<TRANSISTOR>Q7515</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR>,...) without desoldering them? Or do you think they could be the problem?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message: There is no short, CPU core has low resistance like normal. Put on a heat sink and see if the board has video. Also resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> as that is the common issue on these.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan spin
threads.message:
Great, thank you! 
I haven't thought there CPU resistance would be so low.
Now everything works fine! Macbook running perfectly again!

Thanks a lot guys!!!
